text: 4 E. A. PIMENTEL AND J.M. URBANO A second challenge comes from the eventual collapse of the ellipticity in (??). Indeed, along, the first equation either degenerates or blows up, depending on  In particular, we allow this variable exponent to oscillate around hence, the system may switch between the singular and the degenerate regimes. Our approach deals with this difficulty in a seamless fashion, which is in itself an unusual feature that deserves to be highlighted. We now list the main assumptions on the data of the problem. Through- out the paper, we say a constant is universal if it only depends on the data. A 1 (Uniform bound on). The function is bounded from below and there exists a constant such that The lower bound on implies that solutions to the first equation in (??) are locally bounded. But, by considering a possibly unbounded (from above) function, we completely detach the analysis from the constant- exponent setting. Indeed, were bounded and satisfying the next assump- tion, the variable exponent setting would not present extra challenges vis- a-vis the constant case. A 2 (Lipschitz continuity of). The function is Lipschitz continuous and there exists such that  Notice that A?? does not imply to be a Lipschitz continuous expo- nent. Even if is H Ãàolder continuous, the composite function is, a priori, merely H Ãàolder continuous. A 3 (Uniform bounds on ). The function is bounded and there exists a constant, to be fixed later and depending only on the data, such that  The upper bound on plays a critical role in the approximation methods  put forward further in the paper. Perhaps more subtle is the fact that is determined endogenously, in the context of the fixed-point argument in section ??.
